sentences.text: In spite of over two decades of intense research , illumination and pose invariance remain prohibitively challenging aspects of face recognition for most practical applications .

The objective of this work is to recognize faces using video sequences both for training and recognition input , in a realistic , unconstrained setup in which lighting , pose and user motion pattern have a wide variability and face images are of low resolution .

In particular there are three areas of novelty : -LRB- i -RRB- we show how a photometric model of image formation can be combined with a statistical model of generic face appearance variation , learnt offline , to generalize in the presence of extreme illumination changes ; -LRB- ii -RRB- we use the smoothness of geodesically local appearance manifold structure and a robust same-identity likelihood to achieve invariance to unseen head poses ; and -LRB- iii -RRB- we introduce an accurate video sequence '' reillumination '' algorithm to achieve robustness to face motion patterns in video .

We describe a fully automatic recognition system based on the proposed method and an extensive evaluation on 171 individuals and over 1300 video sequences with extreme illumination , pose and head motion variation .

On this challenging data set our system consistently demonstrated a nearly perfect recognition rate -LRB- over 99.7 % on all three databases -RRB- , significantly out-performing state-of-the-art commercial software and methods from the literature .

This work describes the proposed method, which addresses the challenges of illumination and pose invariance. Our system, based on the proposed method, utilizes these video sequences to achieve a nearly perfect recognition rate, demonstrating its effectiveness in recognizing faces under difficult conditions. The method has a broader term, encompassing the recognition system that also relies on the proposed method. This work utilizes the challenging data set, which includes over 1300 video sequences characterized by significant variations in lighting and head poses. The evaluation of illumination and pose invariance remains a challenge for face recognition, but our system effectively addresses these issues, showcasing its capabilities in recognizing faces accurately.

The evaluation of the recognition system is conducted on a comprehensive dataset consisting of 1300 video sequences, which includes significant variations in illumination, pose, and head motion. This evaluation also involves 171 individuals, highlighting the system's capability to operate under challenging conditions. The video sequences exhibit extreme illumination, pose, and head motion variation, which pose challenges for achieving pose invariance in face recognition. Furthermore, the evaluation demonstrates the recognition rate of our system, which utilizes these video sequences for training and recognition. This work emphasizes the importance of addressing generic face appearance variation and face motion patterns, both of which are critical for effective face recognition in most practical applications. Despite the challenges posed by illumination and head motion variation, the system aims to accurately recognize faces across diverse conditions.

Head motion variation is a specific aspect of pose, which refers to the orientation and position of a person's head and face. Over two decades of intense research has been focused on improving face recognition technology, particularly in realistic, unconstrained setups that accommodate significant variability in lighting and pose. Extreme illumination, a broader term encompassing illumination changes, poses challenges for face recognition systems, especially when dealing with low-resolution face images that represent the biometric features of individuals. Video sequences are crucial as they serve as both training and recognition input for these systems. Additionally, unseen head poses, which are variations not included in training data, further complicate recognition efforts. The photometric model of image formation can be effectively combined with generic face appearance variation to enhance performance under challenging conditions. Our system has demonstrated superior performance, outpacing methods from the literature, which are broader terms for established techniques in face recognition. This achievement is supported by a comprehensive dataset of over 1300 video sequences, showcasing the system's robustness against extreme variations in illumination, pose, and head motion.

Face motion patterns are closely related to video, as they represent the variations in facial movements captured in video sequences. The photometric model of image formation is a specific instance of the broader photometric model, which describes how light interacts with surfaces to create images. In the context of face recognition, the training and recognition input is a subset of the broader training process, which is essential for teaching models to recognize patterns. Our system has outperformed state-of-the-art commercial software, demonstrating superior performance in face recognition tasks. This work, which is part of ongoing research, aims to develop a face recognition system that utilizes video sequences, a broader category that encompasses the specific video formats used. Additionally, generic face appearance variation is a statistical model that captures the diverse characteristics of human faces, contributing to improved recognition across varying conditions. The recognition accuracy of our system exceeds 99.7% on all three databases, which are organized collections of data used for evaluation. This achievement is the result of over two decades of intense research focused on overcoming challenges in illumination and pose invariance in face recognition technology.
